parts.title: Exploring the Purpose and Structure of Morphology
parts.body: Morphology is the study of the structure of complex words. Its existence in language provokes questions about why it is distinct from syntax and other elements of grammar. One might explore the possibility that morphophonology, a phenomenon where the same item appears in different shapes (like "man" and "men"), is linked to language evolution. The design of morphology may not be fully optimized for communication or cognition, having evolved due to certain aspects of human cognition and expression. This book applies abductive reasoning, a form of logic seeking the best explanation, to understand these language structures, and acknowledges that these aspects could appear messy, surprising, or unnecessary if other cognitive features had existed differently.

parts.title: Design Flaws in Biology and Language
parts.body: The text discusses the complexity and potential inefficiencies within human biology and language design. Vertebrates, for example, have a maladaptive design flaw where the digestive and respiratory systems cross in the throat, creating a risk of choking. This is due to a "historical legacy" where past evolutionary changes did not optimize the structure as well as possible. Similar criticisms are made about human language, questioning if it too reflects design flaws not seen due to lack of comparison with another intelligent, communicative species. The text then examines language morphology (structure of words) and syntax (structure of sentences). Human language uses two systems: one for syntax and one for morphology, unlike what might be expected from an efficiently designed system. The "sing-sang" and "pig-hunter" questions highlight differences between how syntactic and morphological patterns are utilized, raising the question of why multiple grammatical systems exist and whether they might be considered poor design. The section suggests that answering these questions could reveal subtleties in the evolution of human language.

parts.title: Minimalism, Morphology, and Linguistic Imperfections
parts.body: In linguistics, Minimalism is a theory that explores the reasons behind linguistic imperfections like syntactic displacement. This happens when words like a topicalized item or a question word shift in sentences, such as in (37a), "Beans I like," or in (38a), "Who did you see?" The theory seeks to understand why languages are not "perfect" syntactically, using structures like (37b) "I like beans" and (38b) "you see who" as more "ideal." The debate focuses on whether these displacements are inherent imperfections or if they serve some function driven by other grammatical properties like morphology. Morphology plays a role in explaining these imperfections because words contain phonetic features (how they sound) and semantic features (what they mean). However, they can also have features that do not fit either category, like the "person" feature on verbs. In sentence (42), "Clinton seems to have been elected," the verb seems agrees with Clinton but the "third person" suffix "-s" doesn’t add meaning or sound beyond fulfilling a grammatical requirement. This complexity arises when morphology tries to address displacement issues by erasing or checking uninterpretable features, relating them to corresponding interpretable features to achieve syntactic goals.

parts.title: Sound Changes and Morphology Complexities
parts.body: The discussion highlights the impact of sound changes and analogy in morphology, showing that while some forms of sound-change resistance can maintain grammatical uniformity, they aren't always successful. One example in English is the past-tense formation of verbs like heave, where historically, forms like heft existed but were eventually regularized to heaved. The chunk also mentions how languages sometimes counteract sound-changes to reduce morphological complexity, indicating this process can lead to stable morphological forms. Yet, despite the success in some languages, the phenomenon of allomorphy illustrates a blend of analogies within language that complicate a rigid pattern of sound changes beyond individual cases, needing broader explanations for cognitive acceptance. The chunk delves into the concept of sound-change regularity and morphological exceptions, questioning why languages cannot always counteract phonological changes. The author suggests hypothetical languages, like Esperanto, which follow a One-Form-One-Meaning rule, contrasting with languages like English that exhibit complex allomorphic patterns due to historical sound changes. These languages could present a simpler linguistic model but might not exist due to the inherent complexity found in actual linguistic evolution. A hypothetical researcher may find that complete uniformity in sound-meaning relationships would be impractical despite being theoretically plausible, pointing to a broader linguistic evolutionary force shaping complex morphology beyond singular languages.

parts.title: Resolving Synonymy Dilemmas in Protolanguage
parts.body: Protolinguistic speech could face synonymy dilemmas if it was as fluent as modern speech, leading to challenges for the brain's organization of language. There are standard ways to resolve these dilemmas: by discarding synonyms or treating combined forms as a single vocabulary item. In isolated synonymies, one might eliminate all but one synonym, like choosing only one form for "stream" from forms like [Xut] and [Xyt]. This concept is similar to morphological changes in linguistics known as levelling. As an alternative, a synonymous dilemma can be resolved by interpreting a collocation as a single vocabulary item, especially if it acquires a unique context-specific meaning, which avoids synonymy by changing how the brain interprets the words rather than changing their phonological form.

parts.title: Hungarian Verb Inflection and Vocabular Clarity
parts.body: Hungarian verbs exhibit suffixes signaling tense, mood, number, and definiteness, with significant diversity across verb paradigms. Vowel harmony is prevalent; however, the focus is on subjective person-number suffixes in the present tense. This complex variation resonates with the challenge of synonymy avoidance. Upon examination, plurals exhibit simpler patterns, allowing vocabular clarity. In contrast, singulars manifest ambiguous paradigmatic choices, suggesting domain differentiation in vocabular clarity. Constraints like phonological context influence suffix alternates, prompting comparisons to the flexibilities seen in languages like Javanese, where vocabulary differentiation aligns with social and phonetic considerations.

parts.title: Multivocabular Approach to Hungarian and Latin Inflections
parts.body: Multivocabular Approach to Hungarian and Latin Verbal and Nominal Inflections In the study of Hungarian and Latin languages' morphology, traditional methods encounter limits, especially in dealing with unexplained discrepancies in vowel harmony and inflectional suffixes across verb classes. In Hungarian, back-vowel verb stems uniformly receive back-vowel suffixes, whereas front-vowel verbs sometimes attract back-vowel suffixes. This exception is historically attributed to a once-present high back unrounded vowel, now replaced by a fronted /i/. Despite traditional phonological methods—such as considering this vowel present at a deeper level or attributing a lexical ‘exception feature’ to verbs—these strategies fall short in explaining the inconsistencies within modern Hungarian verbal morphology. Hungarian Verbal Obsolescence further complicates matters as traditionally four inflectional classes now operate as two in colloquial Hungarian. Latin nominal inflection presents another challenge, marked by the complexity and dimly clarified inflectional patterns. Interestingly, the division of inflections into classes doesn't stem solely from semantic or syntactic needs but also from a pursuit of synonymy avoidance. This avoidance leads to extraordinary parallels and peculiarities, such as the cognitive processing of class distinctions—like distinguishing verbal inflection classes through vowel harmony or gender roles. Although external stimuli and internal grammatical drives contribute to these changes, the lack of clarity in vocabular structure and inherited morphological patterns create ongoing challenges for linguists attempting to elucidate the brain's handling of language evolution.

parts.title: Paradigmatic Uniformity and Implication in Stem Alternation Patterns
parts.body: The text discusses the role of uniformity and predictability in the distribution of stem alternants in languages like Dhaasanac, Italian, and Russian. In Dhaasanac, the language displays a clear pattern where two verb stems, A and B, appear consistently across different grammatical categories without phonologically motivated variation. This uniformity allows the stems to be distinguished based solely on their distribution across the paradigm, avoiding synonymy problems. A similar pattern of uniform distribution is noticed in Italian, with paradigmatic predictability helping in categorizing verbs into distinct stem-alternation classes even if there is no phonological similarity between alternants. Russian noun stress patterns present a more complex scenario where stress shifts do not always uniformly align with grammatical categories. For example, early stress in the accusative singular implies early stress in the nominative plural, showcasing an implicational relationship. While Russian stress patterns diverge from Dhaasanac and Italian's uniformity, a nested pattern of implications still offers a clue to how learners might organize the system in their brains, maintaining a systematic if not completely mutual implication across forms.

parts.title: Exploring the Evolutionary Perspectives on Derivation and Lexical Storage
parts.body: In this chapter, we explore the concept of cliché patterns in language evolution, which are *recurring combinations of items* like actions with temporal markers, resembling modern syntactic structures. Chapters 5 and 6 focused on inflectional morphology, where forms are altered to convey grammatical information (e.g., tense, number). We examined how historical syntagmatic and paradigmatic features helped avoid modern linguistic *synonymy*. However, *derivational morphology* and *compounding*, which involve creating new words or altering word forms for lexical variety, have not been addressed. Understanding their evolutionary basis may clarify why these elements are often stored in the brain's lexical system rather than being generated anew each time.

parts.title: Phrases in Compounds and Morphology Evolution
parts.body: This section explores the possibility of phrases appearing within compound words, offering both examples and theories to analyze how such occurrences happen. For instance, the phrase "American history" in American history teacher can be understood as a compound where "history" is modified by "American," forming a phrase inside the compound. However, phrases cannot freely appear in compounds unless they are institutionalized or well-recognized combinations. The text suggests that certain compound structures with phrases work because the phrase is an already established cliche, like "capital cities." The summary highlights that this reflects morphology's evolution where structure arose from conventionalized combinations. This implies morphological evolution allows stored expressions in language to become parts of compounds. Nevertheless, the notion that syntactic phrases might form the second element in compounds does not gain much support, indicating a bias towards having recognizable words at the end of compounds. This exploration shows the boundary that separates morphology from syntax in the creation of compounds and phrases.

parts.title: Abductive Reasoning in Language Evolution
parts.body:
Understanding Language Evolution

In the study of language evolution, abductive reasoning is crucial because direct experimentation is not possible. Palaeontologists and cosmologists also rely on abductive arguments to make sense of unobservable phenomena. A successful abductive argument connects the dots between apparently unrelated facts, leveraging well-observed truths and plausible assumptions. This method becomes even more compelling when it leads to novel predictions regarding language characteristics that are otherwise inexplicable through current theories.

Unraveling Morphological Mysteries

One perplexing aspect observed is that derived words and compounds tend to develop semantic idiosyncrasies more frequently than phrases do, sometimes requiring special storage in the lexicon. The book suggests this could be due to language stages predating full syntactic development, where new vocab items naturally accumulated idiosyncratic meanings to ensure they differed from existing ones. Analyzing facts A-C with observations D-G and assumptions H-M could potentially lead to innovative insights that explain both uniform and nested stem-alternation patterns as found in languages like Italian and Russian.
